description: After the ignorant lawyer Ignoramus, the titular character in the 1615 play Ignoramus by the English playwright Georges Ruggle; from Latin ignōrāmus (“we do not know, we are ignorant of”), the first-person plural present active indicative of ignōrō (“I do not know, I am unacquainted with, I am ignorant of”).

entries.meaning: A totally ignorant person—unknowledgeable, uneducated, or uninformed; a fool.

description: Directly from Latin ignōrāmus (“we do not know”).

entries.meaning: (law, dated) A grand jury's ruling on an indictment when the evidence is determined to be insufficient to send the case to trial.

verbs.description: ignoramus (third-person singular simple present ignoramuses, present participle ignoramusing, simple past and past participle ignoramused)

entries.meaning: (law, transitive) To make such a ruling against (an indictment).
